title: Chapter 354
content: # Chapter 354 A notification chimed. > [You have discovered a hidden feature in White Fang!] > [The information about White Fang has been updated.] Grid held his breath as new text materialized before his eyes. --- **+9 True White Fang** **Rating:** Legendary **Durability:** 170/609 **Attack Power:** 1,015 + 539 * Attack speed will increase by 10 + 3%. * Skill damage will increase by 15 + 7%. * Ignores 25 + 15% of the target's defense. * Slashing attacks will add an additional 20 + 10% damage. * After succeeding in three combos, further damage will be dealt in the form of cutting damage. * The skill **'Heart Selection'** will be generated. * The curse **'Bunhelier's Gaze'** will be applied. *It was produced by smelting the fang of the evil dragon Bunhelier, giving it ultimate power. But it contains a curse. The owner will be followed by Bunhelier's Gaze.* *The great demon Drasion sealed a portion of the sword's power to avoid this gaze, but the legendary blacksmith Grid released the seal.* **Weight:** 887 --- **[Heart Selection]** Passive. When striking at the target's heart (including both normal and skill attacks), there is a normal chance that double the damage will be dealt. There is also a low chance of instantly killing the opponent. **Resources Consumed:** None. **Skill Cooldown Time:** None. --- **[Bunhelier's Gaze]** Curse. The evil dragon Bunhelier is always watching over you. You might be attacked on a day when Bunhelier is feeling grumpy. **Skill Activation Condition:** Random. --- > [Information about 'Bunhelier's Fang' used to make the item has been obtained!] > [The skill proficiency of (Understanding of Gods' Weapons) Legendary Blacksmith's Craftsmanship Skill has increased by 10%.] *Amazing.* Grid's pulse quickened. Legendary skills had always carried a persistent burden. The long cooldown times and resource consumption were bad enough, but the real problem lay deeper. They leveled at a glacial pace. The Legendary Blacksmith's Craftsmanship Skill was no exception. Three years in Satisfy. Three years of grinding, forging, and refining. Countless hours at the anvil. All of it had only pushed the skill to level seven. The mathematics were cruel. After hitting level seven, each Unique rated item he crafted granted a meager 1% experience. One percent. For items that took hours to produce. But this? Ten percent. Just from analyzing a new material. Dragon bone. The word alone carried weight. *Worth every second.* Grid exhaled slowly. But his satisfaction didn't end there. The appraisal results themselves were staggering. Attack power and durability had jumped by 100 and 200 respectively. A new option materialized where none existed before. *If this is what happens to White Fang...* His thoughts drifted to Iyarugt. The ego sword currently sat at Unique rating, but it possessed growth potential. If it reached Legendary, what would it become? The Heart Selection skill in particular drew his attention. For Kraugel, it would be devastating. The man's control was inhuman. Surgical. He could strike a specific point on command, transforming a passive skill into an execution tool. Then Grid's eyes landed on the final line of text. His face went pale. *A cursed item?* The performance boost meant nothing if it came with a noose. White Fang had improved, yes. But now it carried surveillance. Potential attack. From a dragon. *I screwed up.* The realization hit like a hammer blow. He'd meant to help Kraugel. To repay him for the spar, for the experience. Instead, he'd handed him a ticking bomb. Grid swallowed hard. "What's going on?" Kraugel's voice cut through the silence. His eyes tracked Grid's expression, reading the drain of color from his face. Something was wrong. He reached out and took White Fang from Grid's hands. His eyes scanned the item window. Then he froze. The air between them grew thick. Neither man spoke. The smithy's ambient sounds seemed to fade, leaving only the weight of unspoken words. Grid broke first. "I'm sorry." The words came out rough. Grid forced himself to meet Kraugel's gaze. "I am ashamed." He'd changed. The old Grid would have made excuses, deflected blame, shifted responsibility. But he was Lord of Reidan now. Master of Overgeared. Father to Lord. He had standards to uphold. "I'm really sorry. It wasn't maliciously done." Grid's jaw tightened. "Give me time and I will return the item to its original state." Kraugel remained still, White Fang balanced in his palm. Then his voice emerged, trembling with something Grid couldn't identify. "Amazing." Grid blinked. "What?" "Seeing the hidden abilities of an item and drawing them out..." Kraugel looked up, and his expression carried genuine wonder. "You truly are a legendary blacksmith. Among the two billion users, you're the only one who can do this." He turned the blade, light catching the edge. "It is truly amazing." Grid felt unmoored. How many users could impress the 1st ranker? You could count them on two hands. Maybe one. Yet here was Kraugel, offering praise without reservation. The blade whistled through the air. Once. Twice. Kraugel tested the weight, the balance. "Thank you." "But..." Grid's confusion mounted. This wasn't the reaction he'd anticipated. "The curse..." Kraugel's lips quirked upward. "Thanks to you, I can now own the best item." It wasn't flattery. Kraugel's tone carried conviction. The True White Fang's performance had jumped dramatically. And the Heart Selection skill opened possibilities he'd already started calculating. *I will become two, no three times stronger than before.* The mathematics were simple. Heart Selection required precision. Precision was his specialty. Other users might struggle to proc the passive consistently. For Kraugel, it would be as natural as breathing. "That..." Grid fumbled for words. "Is it okay? There's a curse." Kraugel laughed. Actually laughed. "You were worried about that?" He shook his head. "You don't have to worry about Bunhelier. I remember a verse from the folk song of the Trempet people. 'Evil dragon, a hero sealed it 500 years ago.' It is highly unlikely that Bunhelier will appear at this time." *Where is Trempet?* Grid kept the question internal. Most users explored Satisfy organically, wandering the continents and absorbing local culture. Grid's experience was different. More focused. He'd spent years effectively landlocked in the Eternal Kingdom. Rural villages and their folklore hadn't been priorities. *And he remembers folk songs?* The contrast struck Grid. He played Satisfy with tunnel vision, missing details in pursuit of larger goals. Kraugel operated differently. Sharp. Observant. He absorbed information like a sponge, cataloging even minor details. A folk song from a remote village in a kingdom called Trempet. Of course he remembered it. "So." Kraugel's voice shifted to business. "What is the price I have to pay?" Grid hesitated. The thing he wanted most was obvious. Recruit Kraugel. Bring the 1st ranker into Overgeared. The strategic value alone would be immeasurable. But he couldn't say it. Kraugel had maintained solo status for years despite his ranking. Despite countless offers. The pattern was clear. He valued independence. Forcing the issue would only push him away. *Think.* Grid's growth wasn't just about stats and items. He'd learned to read people. To respect boundaries. "Tell me how to get to the East Continent." Kraugel's shoulders relaxed. "Good." The response was immediate. Kraugel had been carrying weight since the spar. Damage to Reidan's territory during his bout with Piaro. Grid's protection of his experience. Now the White Fang upgrade. The debts had accumulated. Sharing this information would balance the scales. The value was substantial. Grid didn't know it yet, but the route to the East Continent required at least a year of continental exploration. Knowledge gathered from dozens of sources, aligned like puzzle pieces. "There is an archipelago in the sea south of the Sea Kingdom Media called Behen." Kraugel's tone shifted to lecture mode. "It is an archipelago made up of a total of 66 small islands." Grid leaned in, absorbing every word. Kraugel's eyes glinted with challenge. "There is a sage present somewhere called Sticks. If you find him, you will be able to move to the East Continent." "Find him?" Grid caught the implication. "Are you saying that he's hiding in a place that is hard to find?" "The Behen Archipelago is a very dangerous place. You have to cross 66 islands one after another." Kraugel's expression turned serious. "A few high rankers became frustrated and couldn't even pass the 10th island. And Sticks usually lives on the 25th to 29th islands." "Media... Behen... Sticks..." Grid pulled out a notebook. His hand moved quickly, transcribing the information. Kraugel watched him write, and something like excitement flickered across his face. *What island can he reach?* Kraugel's own limit was the 30th island. A wall that even he couldn't overcome. Most users considered it the practical ceiling of current player capability. But Grid had defeated him. Not cleanly, not without help, but he'd won nonetheless. *Maybe he can push further.* Maybe Grid would extract something greater from Sticks. Some reward or knowledge beyond Kraugel's reach. *I am looking forward to it.* The ridicule Grid had endured. The years spent dismissed as talentless, as gear-dependent. Kraugel wanted to see him rise above it. Wanted Grid to grow and, in doing so, push Kraugel himself to new heights. It was the truest desire of someone who'd finally found a worthy rival. *** "Why is it so bustling?" Grid emerged from the smithy with Kraugel beside him, tools put away and repairs complete. He stopped short. The entire Overgeared Guild had assembled outside. Jishuka. Lauel. Regas. Pon. Vantner. Even the secondary members crowded the edges. Every eye fixed on Kraugel. Their intention radiated like heat. *Join us. Be one of us.* Grid's stomach sank. *I failed them.* As leader of Overgeared, he'd promised to recruit the 1st ranker. The expectation hung in the air, unspoken but undeniable. And he couldn't deliver. Guilt twisted in his gut. Grid turned to Kraugel, forcing casualness into his voice. "How is it? Do you want to have a meal with us?" Kraugel's expression shifted. Complicated. The spar had changed things. Grid's liking for Kraugel had grown. The feeling was mutual. Kraugel genuinely wanted friendship with Grid. Believed they could help each other improve. But the crowd was too much. Too eager. Too intense. The Overgeared members stared at him with unblinking focus. Their eyes screamed *be our friend* in silent unison. Kraugel cleared his throat. "My mother suddenly called, so I should go." His hand moved to his menu. "Log out." His avatar dissolved. Silence. Grid stood frozen. The Overgeared members exchanged bewildered glances. The peak of two billion users. The sky above the sky. The absolute leader who monopolized the rankings. Had just used his mother as an excuse to log out. Like an elementary school student caught in an awkward social situation. Grid didn't know whether to laugh or cry at the absurdity.
